title: Financial Goals
description: Explore what you're each working toward financially and how you can support each other.

questions.text: The financial goal that matters most to me right now is...
choices: Building an emergency fund or safety net
Paying off debt or obligations
Saving for something specific
Growing wealth for the future

therapeutic.rationale: Current financial priorities reveal what stage you're in and what feels urgent. Safety-net builders need security; debt-payers need freedom; specific-savers have a target; wealth-growers think long-term. Knowing your partner's priority helps you support it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different priorities may compete for resources. The debt-payer may clash with the saver; the safety-net builder may clash with the wealth-grower. Can you sequence goals or pursue both?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared priority focuses your joint effort. You're working toward the same goal together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What financial goal keeps you up at night? What would achieving it change for you?

questions.text: When I think about financial goals, I tend to...
choices: Set specific targets with timelines
Have general direction without strict plans
Focus on one goal at a time
Keep multiple goals in motion

therapeutic.rationale: Goal-setting style reflects broader planning orientation. Target-setters are structured; direction-havers are flexible; single-focusers concentrate; multi-taskers spread effort. Partners often have different styles.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The target-setter may feel the direction-haver lacks commitment; the direction-haver may feel the target-setter is rigid. Both approaches can work—find what works for you as a couple.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared goal-setting style makes planning easier. You'll naturally approach goals the same way.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you typically set and pursue goals? What helps you follow through?

questions.text: I'd love for us to work toward...
choices: Financial freedom and flexibility
A major purchase or milestone
Being able to give generously
Security for whatever comes

therapeutic.rationale: Shared goals create partnership and motivation. Freedom-seekers want options; milestone-seekers want achievement; givers want impact; security-seekers want protection. Naming a shared goal aligns your efforts.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different aspirations may need sequencing. The freedom-seeker and the milestone-seeker can both get what they want—maybe not at the same time. Talk about order and timing.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared aspiration is powerful. You're rowing in the same direction.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would reaching this goal together mean to you? What would it make possible?

questions.text: When we hit a financial goal, I'd want us to...
choices: Celebrate, then set the next one
Take time to enjoy the achievement
Roll the momentum into something bigger
Reassess what matters most now

therapeutic.rationale: How you respond to achieving goals reveals your relationship with progress. Quick-movers keep pushing; pausers savor; momentum-builders compound; reassessors reflect. Partners may have different rhythms.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The quick-mover may feel the pauser is complacent; the pauser may feel the quick-mover never savors. Make room for both celebration and forward motion.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared celebration style means you'll transition from goal to goal similarly. Enjoy your aligned rhythm.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you achieve something, do you pause to enjoy it or move quickly to what's next? Where does that come from?

questions.text: The best way my partner can support my financial goals is...
choices: Encouraging me and believing in my plans
Helping with practical steps and accountability
Giving me space to manage my own goals
Working on them together as a team

therapeutic.rationale: Support preferences for goals mirror general support styles. Encouragers want belief; helpers want action; space-needers want autonomy; teamers want partnership. Giving the wrong support feels unsupportive.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The encouragement-seeker may feel the helper is controlling; the helper may feel the encourager is passive. Ask: 'What kind of support would help you most right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched support preferences make helping feel natural. You'll instinctively give what your partner needs.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're working toward something, what does ideal support from your partner look like?
